lessons.title: Welcome to CS101!
masteryOutcomes: Understand the course structure and main topics

lessons.title: Naming that tells a story
masteryOutcomes: Rename variables and functions to improve clarity

lessons.title: Crafting docstrings that explain the why
masteryOutcomes: Write docstrings that explain the purpose and usage of functions

lessons.title: Writing comments with real purpose
masteryOutcomes: Add comments that clarify reasoning instead of obvious behavior

lessons.title: Keeping it clean
masteryOutcomes: Apply consistent formatting for whitespace, indentation, and line breaks

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Course map and expectations
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Identify the main topics, goals, and expectations of the course and explain how they connect to real-world programming work.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Habit tracker variables and functions
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Improve clarity by renaming variables and functions in a small habit-tracking script so that names tell a clear story. Output: A short Python script for tracking daily habits where all variable and function names are descriptive and self-explanatory.

Output: A Python module for a study planner where each function has a clear docstring and comments that explain reasoning instead of restating the code.

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Example inputs and outputs
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Practice defining normal and edge-case example inputs and outputs for a small finance or budgeting feature described in words.

lessons.title: Breaking down into subproblems
masteryOutcomes: Decompose problems into subproblems

lessons.title: Defining subproblem inputs and outputs
masteryOutcomes: Define clear inputs and outputs for subproblems

lessons.title: Sequencing subproblems logically
masteryOutcomes: Arrange and implement subproblems in logical sequence

lessons.title: Matching subproblems to patterns
masteryOutcomes: Apply common coding patterns to subproblems

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Expense analyzer subproblems
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice breaking down an expense analyzer into clear subproblems and listing them in a logical order. Output: A written decomposition of the app into numbered subproblems with brief descriptions.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Travel time estimator I/O definitions
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice defining precise inputs and outputs for each subproblem in a simple travel time estimator (e.g., commute planner). Output: A table or list where each subproblem has clearly specified input parameters and expected outputs.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Workout planner sequencing
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice arranging subproblems for a workout planner in a logical sequence and explaining the dependencies between them. Output: An ordered list or flow of subproblems showing how data moves from one step to the next.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Pattern matching for study helper
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice matching each subproblem in a study-session helper (e.g., suggesting breaks, total time, and difficulty) to a common coding pattern such as dictionary lookup, filtering, or accumulation. Output: A mapping where each subproblem is paired with one or more coding patterns and a short justification.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Reading tracker planner - Part 1
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice combining decomposition, input/output definitions, sequencing, and pattern matching to design a reading tracker tool. Output: A mini design document listing subproblems, their inputs/outputs, execution order, and the coding pattern chosen for each.
